title: How many of the following teams will not qualify for the 2018 FIFA World Cup's Round of 16: Argentina, Belgium, Brazil, England, France, Germany, Portugal, Russia, Spain, and Switzerland?
preds: Welp, that was not the result I expected for Germany! Request for resolution submitted, as of the final whistle for the two Group E games.
It's over, Germany is the only one out, the only team I gave near certainty for entering the final stage.
Suspect Germany will not make it to the round of 16.

It's all over for Germany. They have always been a good bet to reach semifinals at least, but here they were decisively beaten by lowly South Korea (but let's not forget the latter reached the semi-final as co-host). It's still possible for either Brazil or Switzerland to stumble at the last. Brazil in particular could find Serbia a tough obstacle in their way.
Croatia replaced the starting goalkeeper, 4 defence men, and others, Iceland failed to take advantage.

Updated for latest results. Only Brazil, Germany and Switzerland are not yet through but have probabilities of 89%, 87% and 96% per five thirty eight as of 6.26.2018: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-world-cup-predictions/
Just Germany, Brazil and Switzerland remaining out of these ten. There is a small probability for "2" using 538, but I'm ignoring that.
Just Germany, Brazil and Switzerland remaining out of these ten. "0" should be 75% using 538's current probabilities, but I'm going to go with my biases here.

Impossible for BOTH Brazil and Switzerland to miss out. Germany + Brazil to miss = 1.4%
Germany + Switzerland to miss = 0.5%

Country: [my updated forecast] vs. [538 on Saturday 12pm CET [1]] 
Argentina: 50% vs. 48% 
Belgium: 100%
Brazil: 90% vs. 89% 
England: 100%
France: 100% 
Germany: 83% vs. 87% 
Portugal: 100%
Russia: 100% 
Spain: 100% 
Switzerland: 95% vs. 96% 
In expectation I have 0.82 teams not making it vs. 538 having 0.8 teams not making it. 
I update in my previous prediction based on feeling in direction of my prediction, i.e. more probability mass for 0 or 1 team. [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-world-cup-predictions/
Slight tweak reflecting Portugal having qualified. Probabilities will change dramatically tomorrow - one way or another - after the Argentina Nigeria match tonight.

Model update. In order of likeliness to progress:
Belgium, England, France, Portugal, Russia, Spain (100%)
Switzerland (99%)
Brazil (92%)
Germany (84%)
Argentina (56%)

Big change since yesterday is Portugal securing their place in the next round. Argentina still a 50:50 chance.  And still a 1 in 4 chance that either Brazil or Germany (or both) will fail to make the 16. It seems kind of funny for 538 to be giving Switzerland a better chance than Brazil of making the 16 from Group E, especially given:
a)  both SWI and BRA are currently tied on 4 points, and are BRA ahead on for-and-against; and
b)  the individual match forecasts have BRA more likely to beat SER than SWI are to beat CRC. However, a closer look shows the reason.  SWI can lose without being overtaken by SER.  BRA _cannot_ lose without being overtaken by SER (and being pushed out of the 16, unless SWI also lose).

Model update. In order of likeliness to progress:
Belgium, England, France, Russia (100%)
Spain (99%)
Switzerland (98%)
Brazil (92%)
Portugal (87%)
Germany (83%)
Argentina (56%)

After Argentina vs Nigeria tomorrow there will be big changes in the probabilities above. A Nigerian win would practically remove the option for "0" - unless Iran beat Portugal today, Conversely an Argentine win, barring a freak result for Iceland over Croatia, would increase "0" to about 65%.

England Belgium Russia Uruguay Croatia are safe. But the rest are are up in the air.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup#Round_of_16

If the math is right, Germany only needs to win by 2 goals over SK to ensure a place in the next round. A win gives them 6 points, Sweden needs a win over Mexico to reach 6 points. Fortunately for Germany, a Mex. loss leaves them with a goal differential that is no higher than +1.  A 2 goal win for Germany ensures at least a second place finish. Brazil still not certain, as the Swiss should get 3 points vs Cost Rica, to ensure qualification.  Brazil needs only a win or a draw vs Serbia to ensure qualification Argentina does not control its own destiny.  Croatia can eliminate Argentina, if they choose to do so.  Croatia currently has 6 points and a +5 goal differential.  If Croatia chose to lose to Iceland, Iceland finishes with 4 points, and a goal differential (currently at -1) of either zero or higher if Croatia wants to give away more of their +5 differential.  That would leave Argentina in need of  a +4 goal win vs Nigeria in order to match Iceland.   ...If Croatia does not lose to Iceland, Argentina needs a win against Nigeria to move on.  It's up to Croatia, resting the entire starting roster to prep for the next round may be enough to keep the Argentines out. Portugal only needs a draw vs Iran to move both Spain and Portugal to the next round, but the strategy likely depends on the seeding in Group "A" after the Russia / Ukraine match.

Germany pulls their odds up with a last minute win over Sweden. So that leaves Argentina as a 50:50 call.  
Brazil, Germany, and Portugal will probably make it through (each with a probability of 0.85 to 0.90), but that still means that there is about a 1 in 3 chance that at least one of these three teams will fail to make the next round. However, chance that all 4 of these teams miss is <0.1% ... out of a total probability for "4 or more" of 0.3%. Other teams with probabilities of 0.96 and up. ************************
REFERENCE
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-world-cup-predictions/

With two rounds of the group matches complete, the only one of these teams still looking vulnerable is Argentina. There would need to be some possible though less likely results (such as Serbia beating Brazil, or Sweden beating Mexico) for other teams not to reach the last 16.

Country: [my updated forecast] vs. [538 on Saturday 12pm CET [1]] 
Argentina: 50% vs. 48%
Belgium: 90% vs. 96%
Brazil: 95% vs. 89%
England: 90% vs. 96%
France: 100% 
Germany: 80% vs. 64%
Portugal: 95% vs. 86%
Russia: 100% 
Spain: 95% vs. 99%
Switzerland: 95% vs. 96%
In expectation I have 1.1 teams not making it vs. 538 having 1.26 teams not making it.
I update in my previous prediction based on intuition in direction of my prediction. [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-world-cup-predictions/

Moving "zero" from 8 to 24 after the latest round of games. By first drawing with Brazil and now beating Serbia, the Swiss have exceeded my expectations, and are looking safe. Argentina got a reprieve when Nigeria beat Iceland, but they'll still have to beat Nigeria themselves next week. A draw won't be enough. Germany will need to beat Sweden in their upcoming match if they are to move forward. Could be another banana skin.

Big movers today: 
*  Switzerland now a near certainty
*  Argentina's odds up a bit after Nigeria did them a solid against Iceland.

Model update. Argentina's result has shifted this. In order of likeliness to progress:
France (100%)
Russia (100%)
Spain (99%)
England (94%)
Belgium (93%)
Portugal (87%)
Brazil (86%)
Switzerland (67%)
Germany (60%)
Argentina (37%)

Argentina is in most danger - they'll be knocked out if Iceland beat Nigeria today.  Switzerland have a crucial match against Serbia - they could be in trouble if they lose. There's even an outside chance that Germany could be the third team not to qualify if they don't beat Sweden (who knocked out Italy to get to this stage). The position will be much clearer by Sunday.
Qualitative adjustment for the chance of Germany on top of 538 that I might regret.
I skimmed over the results of the passed 2 days, looks good for all teams so far.

Model update. In order of likeliness to progress:
Russia (100%)
Spain (99%)
Belgium (95%)
England (94%)
France (87%)
Portugal (87%)
Brazil (85%)
Argentina (74%)
Switzerland (66%)
Germany (61%)

Russia qualified, Spain almost so, Portugal just have to avoid defeat against Iran. Next up are matches involving France and Argentina - the latter dropped two points against Iceland and will have to do better against Croatia now.
Who knew the home ground advatange would be so big? It's worth half a goal usually but seems to have given the Russkis a +1.

How badly will Spain and Portugal want to avoide the Russia side? Or are the wins against Egypt and the Saudis rather meaningless. Portugal and Spain in an interesting confrontation.  First played to a draw, knowing they May meet again in a later round.  A tie at the group stage is a friendly outcome for these two top members of Group "B" and the Iberian Peninsula....
What next?....The winner of Group "B", will face the 2nd place side in Group "A", and the second place finisher gets the winner of group "A".  Will Russia finish top of group "A", or will it be Uraguay?  And which would you prefer to play in the first knock out round?.....Russia / Uruguay decide the Group "A" outcome Monday at 14:00 UTC.....Spain and Portugal play the 3rd matches against Morocco and Iran, Monday at 18:00 UTC.  Provided both sides win Monday, the match up with either Russia or Uraguay is dependent on total goal differential between Portugal and Spain (both are currently even at +1). Probably reading too much into this to suspect that might have been the reason for the matching 1-0 wins today. Russia through with 0 points for Egypt and the Saudis after 2 matches.
Russia has shored up its  place in the 16 whereas some of the traditional powerhouses are off to a much shakier start.
Spain all but locks it up.  Portugal only vulnerable to a loss to Iran now.

Model update. In order of likeliness to progress:
Russia (100%)
England (95%)
Belgium (94%)
France (88%)
Brazil (86%)
Spain (85%)
Portugal (77%)
Argentina (73%)
Switzerland (67%)
Germany (59%)

The second round of group matches should start sorting the teams out. If Argentina  and Switzerland win against Croatia and Serbia, the probability of all these ten teams going through to the last sixteen will increase - unless of course there is a major upset in one or more of the other games.
Subtle changes, as Russia locks up a final 16 position.
Changes overnight as England and Belgium join Russia as "near certainties" to make the round of 16.

All ten teams have played their first matches, and my initial impression is that the competition is more equal than I expected, with none of the top tier teams (Brazil, Germany, Spain) winning their first games. I had identified Switzerland as the most likely to go out but their draw with Brazil has improved their chances considerably.  However, I had also picked Argentina as a possible upset, and they haven't done themselves any good by drawing with Iceland, but I certainly didn't expect Germany to lose to Mexico. The other second tier teams in this group (Belgium, England, France, Russia and Portugal) have met expectations, though.

1.3 (-.2)  Today's Swede win keeps pressure on Germany.
If: Swede win vs Germany (eliminated)
If: Swede draw vs. Germany (qualification depends on others) Giving Belgium and Englnd near 100% chance
Using this [1] and some compound probability calculations: [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-world-cup-predictions/
Using the 538 model (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2018-world-cup-predictions/) ... as I presume most others are here.

Updated model. Obviously a number of teams dropping points in their opening games has meant that fewer are expected to progress. In order of likeliness:
Russia (94%)
Brazil (87%)
France (87%)
England (87%)
Spain (84%)
Belgium (84%)
Portugal (79%)
Argentina (74%)
Switzerland 66%)
Germany (65%)

Still around 1.53 On today's matches:
Giving Swiss 80% chance of advance.
Dropping Brazil to 90% odds, and
Dropping Germany to 70% chance of advance, yet it may be considerably lower. Next Saturday:
Mexico matches up with the SKoreans - 3 easy points for Mexico, giving them 6, enough to ensure advancing to the second round. 
German - Sweden match. If Germany wins 3 points plus an assumed 3 the following week against SKorea ensures the second round.  Other possibility: if the Swedes get a draw, the standings may be Mex 6, Swedes 3 (from tomorrow's SK match), Germany 1.  Depending on goal differential Mexico may be in a position to rest the entire team in the final match against the Swedes and hand them an assured second place with 6 points.  Lot of ifs, but it may happen. Odd list of countries that have won matches to this point: Russia, Iran, Serbia, Croatia, Mexico, Uruguay, France and Denmark.

Russian (strictly legal) - influence on outcomes?  Environment can influence matches: From: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/soccer-insider/wp/2018/06/17/germany-vs-mexico-2018-world-cup/?utm_term=.3547595cd925
Mexican goaltender Ochoa: “Since the anthem started,” Ochoa said, “everybody knew who the home team was.”  With much of the 78,011 backing them, the Mexicans were unfazed by the four-time world champions and were the superior side in the first half."
........
"Close your eyes, and you would have sworn you had stepped into Estadio Azteca, that madhouse in Mexico City.
“Cielito Lindo,” punctuated by the familiar “ay-ay-ay-ay” singalong, graced the sound system during World Cup pregame frolicking here Sunday.
https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=tD3mr2d-khg#fauxfullscreen
There was also the unscripted noise, that incredible boom that rattles the brain, created by tens of thousands of Mexican soccer supporters, many from homes in the United States, who have journeyed extraordinary distances to watch perhaps the country’s most capable team.
Open your eyes, and you would have seen section after section glazed in green, up and down Luzhniki Stadium, easily outnumbering those backing the opposition, reigning champion Germany."

Thanks @Khalid for pointing to 538's live model that seems to update every minute. I update my numbers a bit in their direction, comparing my initial predictions with their probabilities that individual teams would succeed beyond the group stage. Country: [my forecast] vs. [538 on Sunday 2pm CET]
Argentina: 90% vs. 68%
Belgium: 90% vs. 87%
Brazil: 90% vs. 90%
England: 50% vs. 85%
France: 50% vs. 89% 
Germany: 98% vs. 89%
Portugal: 90% vs. 73%
Russia: 50% vs. 92%
Spain: 90% vs. 87% 
Switzerland: 80% vs. 55% 538 currently expects 1.85 of the listed teams not to make it. I will take this and move some more probability mass from 3 or more teams to 1 or 2 teams compared to my previous prediction.

Swiss and now Argentina seem to be the most likely candidates. After today's matches, France slightly more likely to qualify from a high level, while Argentina now have a real chance at not qualifying (maybe 30%?). Giving both Iceland and Croatia even odds with Argentina (67% each) to move on.  Swiss have a tough group with Costa Rica and Serbia in contention for 2nd spot, although, so far, the EU is getting great results against non-EU nations.

Swiss now seem the most likely to fail, however the Swiss traditionally give up few goals and sometimes advance on 3 points from draws. Russia now seems likely to move on. Portugal and Spain continue as favorites.  Likely group outcome is Port & Esp 7 pts, Iran 3 and Moracco 0.
Looks like the Group "B" championship will be determined by who can score the most goals against Morocco and Iran in the remaining matches (both are defensive teams - with Iran even more motivated to reduce goals against with a win in hand).

Russia wins 5:0 in opening match --> medium update that russia will make it to the next stage --> taking some probability mass from 3 or more teams not making it closer to only 1 or 2 groups not making it.

Saudi gift of 5 goals, 3 late, to WC host and OPEC teammate  Russia makes Russia progression to second round more likely.  Might get to second round with only a tie against Egypt on goal deferential. Suspect the Saudis will play tougher against Egypt. Spain suspect with firing of coach just before the tournament.

If group performance were predicted by FIFA world ranking alone, all teams but Russia would go through to the knock outs. There is still a high level of uncertainty, as strong teams will under perform and underdogs will overcome. Additionally, there are many groups where there are strong competitors close to these teams in FIFA ranking. For instance, England are 13th and Group G rivals Tunisia are 14th. At this stage, I have based my forecast on the FIFA rankings, accounting for uncertainty. The closing date for this question means forecasts can be made after watching a few matches and assessing team performance then.
These are all the favorites. The odds of one not getting to the round of 16 are already low, but the odds of at least one are considerable. Something always goes wrong along the way.

Slightly increasing odds on 2. 
Argentina loses top goalkeeper. In addition it seems one injury to Messi may end Argentinian WC.
http://www.sportingnews.com/soccer/news/romero-confirms-he-will-stay-at-man-united/1tz1mj9lih5t91jvrag9p75tsh In addition to Argentina and Russia, the following pairs must both advance from 4 team groups: Belgium and England; Spain and Portugal; and Brazil and the Swiss.  Depending on how the first two matches in thes groups go the leader in the group often has the opportunity to rest players in the final and in effect influence the 2nd place result.
Flattening out the probabilities compared to my initial guesstimate yesterday of 5/45/40/10/0.

Model update as for Winner forecast. Most likely to progress, in order: 
Brazil (91%)
Germany (91%)
Spain (87%)
Russia (87%)
England (85%)
Belgium (83%)
Argentina (81%)
France (78%)
Portugal (77%)
Switzerland (58%)

Betting markets make Brazil (2/17), France (1/10), Germany (1/7), Spain (1/10) and Belgium (1/10)  clear  odds-on favorites to win their groups and reach the last 16.  Other odds on favorites to reach the last 16 are England (1/6) and Portugal (1/3), both expected to come second in their groups.  Russia (7/18 to qualify) has home advantage which generally takes teams one or two stages ahead of expectations, plus they should beat Egypt and Saudi Arabia in their group.  That leaves two teams to consider.  There have been surprises in every World Cup, with usually at least one big name failing to reach the knockout stages, and often one African country making it.  Historically, South American countries have rarely done well when the World Cup is in Europe (Brazil being an exception), so Argentina - despite a much higher FIFA rank and 3/19 odds to qualify - may struggle against Croatia (4/7) Nigeria (11/4), and the giant-killers of 2014, Iceland (4/1). Current odds for Switzerland to reach the last 16 are 11/10, compared to 5/4 for Serbia, so it is on the margin and could go out earlier.  Overall, I think at least one of the listed ten won't reach the last 16, with the most likely being Switzerland getting edged out by Serbia. There is likely to be at least one additional surprise, which could be England (with much better odds to qualify compared to Tunisia, but they are both ranked almost equally by FIFA) or Argentina (as explained above). By definition, a surprise could be any other team too. (Odds are taken from www. oddschecker.com)

Giving England a 10% chance, based on long shot Tunesia and Enland's uncertain defence.
Giving Russia a 30% chance, having played no qualifying marches as tournament host, offset with home advantage and minimal travel schedule, but Egypt is the only competition for the number 2 spot in Group "A".
Giving France a20% chance due to strong competition from both Peru and Denmark in Group "C".
Giving Spain a 20% chance, as Portugal may be the Group favorite, and Morocco and Iran are adequate defensively.
Swiss get a 67% chance, Brazil is clear favorite in the Group and Costa Rica and Serbia have a chance.
Everyone else should easily move on.
Total odds seem to be around 1.5 failures for second round, increasing the odds slightly due to many wildcards: injuries, red & yellow cards, penalty kicks, and the opportunity for a Group leader to throw the last match to keep a competitor out of the second round.

there are always a couple of "sure" teams who underperform. I consider Russia and Switzerland not to have an easy road to go through. Then, there might always be a surprise of a "big" team not going through.
According to the betting odds five of these have about 66% of going through, 2 a bit better than 50%, with three others considerably behind: Portugal, Russia and Switzerland.

WoC PoT.  Russia or Switzerland. Even in easy group and home crowd advantage the pressure and vodka might be too much. Will any be banned for doping? Doubtful as the spooks will switch the test samples, secret trapdoor in the lab closet to break and enter quickly and easily.  Maybe Belgium? They're the weakest 3 it seems.

Argentina: 5th in world ranking, in group D with Iceland, Croatia and Nigeria (22th, 18th, 47th) --> 90% chance to preceed
Belgium: 3rd in world ranking, in group G with Panama, Tunisia and England  (55th, 14th, 13th) --> 90%
Brazil: 2nd in world ranking, in group E with Switzerland, Costa Rica and Serbia (6th, 25th, 35th) --> 90%
England: 13th in world ranking, in group G with Belgium, Panama and Tunisia (3rd, 55th, 14th) --> 50%
France: 7th in world ranking, in group C with Australia, Peru and Denmark (40th, 11th, 12th) --> 50%
Germany: 1st in world ranking, in group F with Mexico, Sweden and South Korea (15th, 23rd, 61st) --> 98%
Portugal: 4th in world ranking, in group with Spain, Morocco and Iran (8th, 42nd, 36th) --> 90% 
Russia: 66th on the Fifa World Ranking, but also in a weak group with Saudi Arabia, Uruguay and Egypt, + host bonus --> ~50% to proceed
Spain: 8th in world ranking, in group with Portugal, Morocco and Iran (4th, 42nd, 36th) --> 90% 
Switzerland: 6ths in world ranking, in group E with Brazil, Costa Rica and Serbia (2nd, 25th, 35th) --> 80% I have 1 group with 98% --> this will most likely make it
I have 5 groups with a 90% --> in expectation there is 1/2 a team of those that won't make it
I have 1 group with a 80% --> in expectation there is 1/5th of a team that won't make it
I have 3 groups with a 50% --> in expectation 1.5 teams of those won't make it In combination: I expect 2.2 teams on the list to not make it, and lay over it something of a Poisson distribution over it (https://www.intmath.com/blog/wp-content/images/2010/05/poisson-continuous.gif) so I conclude with: 0: 10%
1: 25%
2: 40%
3: 20%
4+: 5%

Rossiya is 100% certain. Putin power alone guarantees it! Who are the bookmakers favourites? Brazil, Germany, Spain, France and Argentina are the bookies’ favourites for this edition while Panama’s and Saudi Arabia are put at 1000/1. According to US website FiveThirtyEight, Russia’s group is the easiest one in modern World Cup history, featuring Uruguay, Egypt and Saudi Arabia. At the same time, no group cracks the top 10 most difficult since 1986: the campaign of the big favourites is thus expected to be smooth at least until the knockout stage. Nate Silver’s website, however, predicted Brazil as 2014 World Cup winner but the cup was eventually lifted by Germany. Brace yourselves for surprises.
http://www.euronews.com/2018/05/18/2018-fifa-world-cup-the-euronews-guide That said the World Cup has already surprised me bu I still expect the favorites to win.

Quite a number very comfortable to qualify (POR,SPA,ARG,BRA,SWI,GER). FRA exit unlikely, as would require both Peru and Denmark to outperform expectations, but an outside possibility.  Either ENG or BEL could be overcome by Tunisia; unlikely, but most plausible way for one if the main 9 listed not to make it. Russia shouldn’t be good enough to get out of group, but home advantage might allow them to scrape through (albeit with a low probability).
Depends on injuries, refs and that video-ref thingy. Oh and how many players are poisoned/drugged by Putina ;-p
Russia and Switzerland are weak & picking 1 from Belgium, England and Brazil/Argentina
Just a SWAG at this point...
